stem: A 4-year-old child who underwent a Fontan procedure (stage 3 cardiac repair) 48 hours ago develops sudden cyanosis and respiratory distress. Based on the documentation, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, the two actions the nurse should take, and the two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: 07:15. Acute desaturation in a post-cardiac surgical child. SpO2 72% on 100% FiO2. Gasping respirations noted.
Background: Hypoplastic Left Heart Syndrome (HLHS). Fontan procedure completed 48 hours ago. Baseline SpO2 94% on room air.
Assessment: Child is cyanotic and appears 'blue-gray'. Chest tube drainage is suddenly bloody (100 mL over the last hour). BP 68/40, HR 158, RR 42. Fontan pressure is elevated at 22 mmHg. D-Dimer is 2,800 ng/mL.
Recommendation: STAT consult with the cardiac surgeon. Anticipate orders for anticoagulation and further diagnostic imaging to rule out pulmonary embolism. Prepare for potential interventions to stabilize pulmonary blood flow.

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content: BP 68/40, HR 158, RR 42, SpO2 72% on 100% FiO2. Liver is enlarged (2cm below rib).

actionOptions.text: Initiate IV Heparin or Enoxaparin as prescribed
Maintain the head of the bed in a high-Fowler's position
Instruct the child to blow through a straw to increase lung pressure
Apply cooling blankets to reduce the heart's metabolic load

parameterOptions.text: Continuous pulse oximetry and respiratory rate
Active bleeding from surgical sites or chest tubes
Presence of a positive Trousseau sign

rationale.correct: This is a Pulmonary Embolism (c1) in a high-risk pediatric cardiac patient after a Fontan procedure. Post-Fontan physiology relies on passive (low-pressure) pulmonary blood flow; any clot in the lungs causes immediate backup into the systemic venous system (High Fontan pressure/Enlarged liver) and severe hypoxia. The sudden bloody chest tube drainage and elevated D-dimer further support this diagnosis. Priority actions are stopping clot growth with Heparin or Enoxaparin as prescribed (a1) and optimizing ventilation via HOB elevation (a2) to reduce preload. Monitoring focus is on oxygenation (p1) and bleeding risks from the new anticoagulation (p2).
clinicalPearls: Fontan patients have slow-moving blood in the 'pulmonary conduits,' making them extremely prone to clots/PE.
In Fontan physiology, there is no pump (Ventricle) for the lungs; the heart relies on low pulmonary vascular resistance to work.
D-Dimer is a helpful screening tool, but imaging (Echo/CT) is needed for confirmation.

questionTrap.trap: Increasing airway pressure (PEEP/Straw blowing) to 'open the lungs'.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Increasing airway pressure in Fontan circulation will actually BLOCK blood flow from the body to the lungs because there is no ventricle to push against that pressure. Keep pressure low; use HOB instead.

mnemonic.title: Fontan Flow
mnemonic.expansion: F-Fast pulses. O-Oxygen low. N-Needs blood flow. T-Thrombosis threat. A-Anticoagulation first. N-No PEEP.
